intro: Floscopa rivularioides, commonly known as the riverbank bellflower, is a perennial herbaceous plant native to the wetlands and riverbanks of eastern North America. It features slender, erect stems that bear opposite, lance-shaped leaves with a smooth, waxy surface. The plant produces showy, bell-shaped flowers in shades of blue to purple, typically blooming from June to August. Floscopa rivularioides thrives in moist, well-drained soils and is often found in riparian zones. It plays a role in supporting local pollinators and is valued for its ornamental appeal in wetland gardens.
